com.codename1.webrtc

Class RTC

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.codename1.webrtc.RTC
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable

    public class RTC
extends Object
implements AutoCloseable

    The main access point for WebRTC. An RTC instance wraps a BrowserComponent, which is used to host all WebRTC sessions. Use the getVideoComponent() to access the visual component associated with the RTC session. This component can be placed into a UI hierarchy.

    Creating RTC Object

    Use createRTC() to create a new RTC object. All videos, peer connections, data channels, etc.. will be created by and bound to the resulting RTC object.

    RTC.createRTC().then(rtc->{
    //  The RTC object is created.  You can now start working with it.
});

    Basic Example

    The following example is a minimal example that accesses the device camera and microphone and streams the output to the screen. It highlights the use of getUserMedia(com.codename1.webrtc.MediaStreamConstraints) to access the device’s camera and microphone. This is based on the Basic getUserMedia demo on the WebRTC web site.

    RTC.createRTC().ready(rtc->{ (1)
       MediaStreamConstraints constraints = new MediaStreamConstraints() (2)
               .audio()
               .echoCancellation(true)
               .noiseSuppression(true)
               .video(true)
               .stream();

       rtc.getUserMedia(constraints).then(stream->{ (3)
           RTCVideoElement video = rtc.createVideo(); (4)
           video.setAutoplay(true);
           video.setSrcObject(stream);
           video.applyStyle("position:fixed;width:100%;height:100%;"); (5)
           rtc.append(video); (6)
       }).onCatch(error-> {
           Log.e(error);
       });
       hi.add(BorderLayout.CENTER, rtc.getVideoComponent()); (7)
       hi.revalidate();
   });

    1. Create the RTC object using createRTC(). This is an asynchronous call which returns an AsyncResource<RTC>.

    2. Set up requirements for accessing user media using MediaStreamConstraints

    3. Call getUserMedia(com.codename1.webrtc.MediaStreamConstraints), to access camera and mic. This is an asynchronous call.

    4. Create a new Video element using createVideo(). A single RTC instance can include multiple video elements.

    5. Set up the video element so that it fills the RTC canvas. RTCElement.applyStyle(java.lang.String) allows you to set arbitrary CSS styles to the video elements. Positioning is relative to the RTC component itself, so in this case with "position:fixed" it will allow us to fill the entire RTC component with the video element.

    6. Append the video to the RTC canvas. Until we do this, the video element will not appear in the RTC component.

    7. Add the RTC’s visual component to the Codename One UI hierarchy.

                                      boolean audio,
                                      boolean video)
        Deprecated. Internal use only

        Internal callback function used by Native interface. Do not use.

        Parameters:
        callbackId - The callback ID
        audio - True if audio permission is granted.
        video - True if video permission is granted.

      • createRTC

        public static AsyncResource<RTC> createRTC()

        Creates a new RTC object.

        Returns:
        Promise that resolves to the resulting RTC object.

      • createRTC

        public static AsyncResource<RTC> createRTC(String htmlBody,
                                           String css)

        Creates a new RTC object. Injects HTML content into the webpage body and CSS into the webpage head that is used to host the RTC.

        Parameters:
        htmlBody - HTML string to inject into the <body> of the page.
        css - CSS styles to inject into a <style> tag in the <head> of the page.
        Returns:
        Promise that resolves to the resulting RTC object.

      • close

        public void close()
           throws Exception

        Closes the RTC session. When you are finished with the RTC session, you should call this method to prevent memory leaks, and free up resources such as the camera and microphone.

        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
        Throws:
        Exception
